div1.p: This document contains discussion regarding the placement of names of individuals involved in the yellow fever experiments on the rolls of the war department and providing pensions to the survivors or widows of those involved. Support for the bill includes statements by Peabody, Ireland, Kean, and representatives from Congress and the Smithsonian.

YELLOW FEVER
----------
div1.p:
HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES,
COMMITTEE ON MILITARY AFFAIRS,
Wednesday, April 11, 1928.

The committee met, pursuant to the call of the chairman, in the
room of the committee in the House Office Building, at 10.30 o'clock
a. m., Hon. John M. Morin (chairman) presiding.
The committee had under consideration the following bill:
[H. R. 11686, Seventieth Congress, first session]

A BILL To provide for the placing of the names of certain individuals on the rolls of the
War Department, and to authorize the Board of Regents of the Smithsonian Institution
to make certain recommendations

Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States
of America in Congress assembled, That in special recognition of the high public
service rendered, and disabilities contracted in the interest of humanity and
science as voluntary subjects for the experimentations during the yellow fever
investigations in Cuba, the Secretary of War be, and hereby is, authorized and
directed to place on the rolls of the War Department, the names of Mrs. Walter
Reed, Mrs. James Carroll, Mrs. Jesse W. Lazear, Doctor Aristides Agramonte;
private John H. Andrus, Hospital Corps; Mr. John R. Bullard, private A. W.
Covington, Twenty-third Battery, Coast Artillery Corps; private William H.
Deans, Troop B, Seventh Cavalry; private Wallace Forbes, Hospital Corps;
private Levi E. Folk, Hospital Corps; private P. Hamann, Twenty-third Battery,
Coast Artillery Corps; private James F. Hanberry, Hospital Corps; Mrs. Warren
G. Jernegan; private John R. Kissinger; Mr. John J. Moran; private William
Olson, Hospital Corps; private Charles G. Sonntag, Hospital Corps; private
Clyde L. West, Hospital Corps; Doctor R. P. Cooke; private Thomas H.
England, Hospital Corps; private James Hildebrand, Hospital Corps; private
Edward Weatherwalks, Hospital Corps. And the Secretary of War is hereby
directed to pay to the foregoing, during the remainder of their natural lives,
the sum of $250 per month in lieu of any and all pensions now received.

SEC. 2. That the Board of Regents of the Smithsonian Institution is hereby
authorized to investigate all cases of citizens employed in the public service of
the United States who through voluntary risk of life and health shall have
rendered conspicuous service to the people of the country, and shall have power
to recommend to the Congress of the United States the amount and nature of
the recognition to which such citizens are justly entitled, and shall report to
the Congress in detail the circumstances surrounding such service.
The CHAIRMAN. The committee will please come to order.

STATEMENT OF HON. J. MAYHEW WAINWRIGHT, A REPRESENTA-
TIVE IN CONGRESS FROM THE STATE OF NEW YORK

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. This hearing is set on H. R. 11686, entitled
“A bill to provide for the placing of the names of certain indi-
viduals on the rolls of the War Department, and to authorize the
Board of Regents of the Smithsonian Institution to make certain
recommendations.”

2
YELLOW FEVER

I introduced this bill at the instance of a prominent organization
in New York whose headquarters are in New York but whose mem-
bership extends over the whole country, the American Association
for Medical Progress.

The degree of interest in the measure in New York is evidenced
by the communications I have received, and particularly by the
keen interest of a group of prominent citizens in my own district.

The immediate primary purpose of the bill is to finally give suit-
able recognition to those in the military service of the United States
who subjected themselves at the risk of their lives, and certainly of
their health, in the experiments that were conducted at Habana
during the American occupation, to determine the source and the
cause of yellow fever. The general subject, I am quite sure, is
familiar to most if not all of the members of the committee. You
will recall that under the leadership of Maj. Walter Reed--and I am
sure General Gorgas came, too--who had the theory that the yellow
fever was transmitted through the mosquito--these very interesting
and extremely hazardous experiments were undertaken.

Some of those who subjected themselves to this risk have been
already recognized, but there are a number who have not been. The
purpose of this bill is, first, to give them a due sentimental recogni-
tion by putting their names on a roll in the War Department, a roll
of honor as it were, and next to make general provision by way of
pension for the survivors and those who have died.

It will be useless for me to undertake to arouse your interest in this
burning subject with which you must be familiar, or to refer to the
obvious considerations involved in this bill not only as it relates to
the recognition of those who made those experiments, but it
affords an incentive and inspiration for the future self-sacrifice of
the same nature in the cause of humanity.

The primary purpose of the bill is as I have stated; but in section
2 it is provided that the Board of Regents of the Smithsonian Insti-
tution shall be an authority to pass upon cases of a similar nature
in the future, and to make recommendation to Congress for suitable
recognition, I quote from the bill, “of citizens employed in the
public service of the United States who through voluntary risk of
life and health shall have rendered conspicuous service to the people
of the country” in the manner suggested.

I have several communications indorsing the bill, one of which I
wish to file, from the medical society of the county of New York;
and also a letter from that distinguished biologist, Prof. Henry
Fairfield Osborn, who is president of the American Association for
the Advancement of Science and affiliated societies, generally ap-
proving of this measure; and I would like to quote the concluding
paragraphing of his letter. [Reading:]

It can not be said that all republics are ungrateful, if France, England,
and Germany, are quick to recognize their heroes; but America, if not un-
grateful, is certainly thus far forgetful of the incalculable service, both human
and economic, rendered by the noble discoverers of the cause of yellow fever
and their aides.

Professor Osborn is not entirely accurate, because as I have said,
Congress has already recognized the principle involved in this meas-
ure, and provision has been made by special bills for two or three of
YELLOW FEVER
3
these individuals; and the question will be presented here whether
the provision made was adequate or not.

I would like to call upon a resident of my own county as the first
speaker, a distinguished educator, who for many, many years has
shown an interest in this matter and has devoted a great deal of time
and thought to it. I would like to call for just a word to the commit-
tee from Dr. James A. Peabody of Morris High School in New
York City.

Mr. QUIN. Before Doctor Peabody starts, I would like to ask you
a question.
Mr. WAINWRIGHT. Yes.

Mr. QUIN. Did we not pension, for his services there, General
Gorgas's widow? It occurs to me that we did that.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. I do not think we pensioned General Gorgas's
widow, but there was a pension for Major Reed's widow. I am not
entirely familiar with that, but General Ireland is here, and I am go-
ing to call him next, and he can explain just what provisions were
made.

Mr. FROTHINGHAM. May I ask what the idea is of section 2? They
have the power now to do that, have they not?

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. I do not so understand. If any recommenda-
tion of that kind was made by the Regents of the Smithsonian Insti-
tution, of course, it would be entirely voluntary. To-day there is
no function devolved upon them by law, and there is no Government
authority to do what this bill contemplates, to provide machinery,for
taking care of cases of this kind in the future.
Mr. JAMES. Is not this broader, in cases of this kind----

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. I wonder if the members of the committee
would permit us to proceed with the hearing, so that we might there-
after take up the technical considerations involved. I can see that
there will be, as the result of the discussions here, some suggestions
for modification of this measure. Maybe we have not the ideal way
of treating it. We are attempting to bring this subject before the
Congress through the committee to see if some suitable method can
not be devised for treating these cases in the future, as well as for
taking care of the people mentioned in the bill.

Doctor Peabody, will you in a few words explain your interest in
this bill, and how it came about? I will state that Doctor Peabody
is head of the Morris High School biology department, which is
one of the large high schools in New York.
STATEMENT OF DR. JAMES A. PEABODY

Doctor PEABODY. I have been tremendously interested in this whole
problem for a great many years. I have taught the subject of
biology in the Morris High School, and as soon as this yellow-fever
story came forward my interest centered greatly on that.

It has been my good fortune to know Mrs. Lazear, whose husband
died of yellow fever out in California. I was also acquainted with
Mr. Kissinger, who was the first one to volunteer for these experi-
ments; and we believe there is no subject in the curriculum of biology
that has any greater lesson of heroism for our children than has this
one of the conquest of yellow fever, and so we appealed to the Ameri-
4
YELLOW FEVER
can Society for Medical Progress to take the leadership in formulat-
ing some possible legislation. Doctor Barrows, of that society, is
present here to-day. He will take it up from this point.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. I will call next on Doctor Barrows. Doctor,
will you explain the purposes of the American Association for
Medical Progress?

STATEMENT OF DR. EDWARD M. BARROWS, REPRESENTING THE
AMERICAN ASSOCIATION FOR MEDICAL PROGRESS (INC.)

Doctor BARROWS. We are a lay organization--that is to say, non-
medical or nonscientific in every sense of the word--with a national
organization.

The general purpose has been to try and impress upon the public
through the schools and colleges, and through the public health
department, or any way we can, some understanding of the methods
and the procedure through which these great discoveries in medi-
cine have been made, such as the yellow-fever experiment, such as
the spotted-fever experiment which is now going on in the Public
Health Service, and the work of Pasteur and Lister, through
which individuals, at the risk of their own lives and health and
everything they ever hoped to have, have been able to solve the great
problems of disease and bring about the mitigation which has so
greatly improved the lot of man, both in America and in Europe.

We were inspired to do that as a matter not only of academic
interest, but because certain conditions in the United States due to
ignorance of this very thing, have led to unscientific and emotional
attacks, perhaps, on the medical practice and medical progress in a
great many ways, in which, without any argument here as to the
point of view that the antivaccinationists and the antivivisectionists
take, they attempt to give the public some kind of a degree of under-
standing of what the work of the laboratory research worker is and
what he does and what his contribution to science has been. That has
been a direct reenforcement to the public-health agencies of the
United States, as we have had evidence everywhere, as well as to the
science teaching in the schools.

It was inevitable, therefore, that with this interest in the face of
yellow-fever experimenters, as evidenced in the case of Private
Kissinger and his fellows a few years ago when this interest began to
arise in that, they should turn to this organization which is the na-
tional representative of prominent laymen, and scientists over the
country should be asked to see what they can do, first toward giving
some kind of recognition to these particular experimenters, and then
to see if anything could be done in the future, so that any man who, in
the course of his duty in carrying on these investigations at the risk
of his life, for which he now receives no credit, should thenceforth
know that there would be some method of national recognition of
what he has done. It is not only a matter of financial reward. Tak-
ing these yellow-fever experiments alone, there were many instances
there in which men who participated in them are not necessarily
poverty stricken in their old age, but we have felt very strongly that
the obligation of the country rested on a wholly different basis; that
whether a private, a colonel, or a doctor in the medical profession,
YELLOW FEVER
5
when a man offers his life, outside of the strict line of his duty, when
he is giving all he has got to give, nothing can pay for that.

On the other hand, there are different forms of recognition which
are appropriate in different cases; perhaps, a medal for some, and a
money grant for others, all depending on the specific nature of the
service performed on the one hand, and on the personality of the
people involved on the other, which would make it incumbent that in
the future there should be an official method by which the value of
the services could be determined by an official body, and the Nation
could express its recognition, in the future, of the services performed
along authoritative, authentic lines indicated.

That, necessarily, could not apply to the past. That is water
under the bridge.

These yellow-fever experimenters went through their ordeal about
18 or 19 years ago. At that time there was no method at all for
making any differentiation, or giving any adequate reward for what
they had done.

Meantime, some of them have died; some of them have disappeared;
some of them are in actual want, as the records show clearly; but in
order to try to complete it down and judge each person's case with
these old men who belong now to a passing generation, who have
given so much time and effort, the best we can do right now is to let
the minimum of the reward we give them be that which would have,
perhaps, been the greatest thing, the national recognition; and then
for those particular experiments, let them go through, and as the
standard method of evidencing our appreciation, and that in the
future a national body of some kind, or a special commission, be
appointed by the President.

I do not need to go into the details. That was rejected. We
might have gotten it through in several years if we could have gotten
the agreement of several hundred men of different ideas as to who
should constitute the commission and what they should do.

I will say parenthetically that we have had a great deal of corre-
spondence from all over the country from lawyers and professional
men and teachers, men such as President Franck, of the University
of Wisconsin, through every rank or walk of life throughout the
country, who have expressed their interest and their opinions on
this bill and as to what should be done about it, and have said that
if we could we should find an authoritative body here in Washing-
ton which could be the recipient for reports of cases of this kind.

I will give you an instance of one of these experiments. Probably
you have followed the investigation by the Public Health Service of
the spotted fever. Two or three men have lost their lives in that.
They are not soldiers, yet their contribution to this country's welfare
is incalculable.
Mr. WAINWRIGHT. If I may interrupt you----
Doctor BARROWS. Yes.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. I noticed in the New York Times of Sunday
last a case of the kind in Montana, of one of the men you refer to,
who had died, and in the dispatch the question was raised as to
“What should we do about cases of that kind?”

Doctor BARROWS. Yes; I think that is the third case, or somewhere
there, in the Public Health Service alone, of men who have sub-
6
YELLOW FEVER
mitted themselves to certain experiments and have paid the penalty
with their lives, just working in their capacity of Government em-
ployees but certainly undertaking risks to try to do everything
possible in the solving of these diseases far beyond what we should
expect of a man on a salary.

I should interpolate one thing, if I may take the time here to
speak, that there are certain of the medical problems which are under
investigation to-day in which a certain amount of human experi-
mentation that is of a most voluntary character is necessary; a
man exposing himself to infection or exposing himself to the results
of some experiment is absolutely essential if the experiment is to be
carried through in its entirety. Of course, any man has a right
to stop when he thinks his own interests are concerned, and say, “I
will go no further”; but they do not do it.

A certain amount of research work and experimentation is impera-
tively necessary in many cases; but after all there is a certain divid-
ing line in certain things in which the final test has to come either
through a man carrying on his own research and experiment just
a little bit beyond the usual line, or else a man accepts them, as in the
case of spotted fever and some other things of that kind. So far as
they are concerned it is all in the day's work, as scientists and as
servants of the public. But after all, we have always felt from our
contacts with the people of the United States--the thinking people
anyway--that the obligation is even greater on the part of the
country to recognize the services and self-sacrifice of men who do
that kind of work, from the selfish point of view, from self-interest
alone; so that when a man is confronted with that question, “Shall
I go ahead and risk my life, or shall I stop right here, as I have
a right to do,” if the decision is for sacrifice he hay at least feel
that he is not going to involve his wife and children or other de-
pendents throughout all the future; that there is such a thing as
gratitude in a republic; that if he has to pay the ultimate penalty he
can at least do it with the feeling that those dependent on him
will be taken care of in the future.

On the other hand, the bill is so framed, as I pointed out, that
it does not contemplate a money grant in all cases for all people.
In some cases, where it is a matter of signal recognition by the
Government, of a man who is otherwise able to take care of him-
self, it will be in the form of a medal, in the form of an official
testimonial that you wanted to give.

I should like to close by pointing out just one or two expressions
in the bill which I know are going to come up before your honorable
body here, and they did come up and have been the subject of a
good deal of anxious study on our part, and I would like to take a
moment to give you the benefit of our action on certain points that
will likely come up here.

I have already alluded to reasons why, in drafting the bill here,
we got the names from the War Department with all the statistics,
and have gotten all the facts as to whatever happened to them after-
wards, and we have presented them here, and ask that all of them
be given enough in their declining years to keep them comfortably
and to take care of any dependents that they may have. That is the
reason for the apparent inconsistency here of colonels and higher
officers, and privates, together. In the particular case they are all
YELLOW FEVER
7
receiving the same reward. This is a matter, really, of taking care
of the old age of men who, after all, have a certain minimum
requirement.

The Board of Regents of the Smithsonian Institution were au-
thorized to investigate all cases. The question of all cases is not
as formidable as it sounds. So far as the intent in this bill is con-
cerned, I think that the number of cases in the last 20 years would
be not more than 15 or 20 at the outside; but they are all important,
and there is no telling at what point that situation is going to
change.

We had already found, I think, as the Congressman has pointed
out, that the Board of Regents would be in the line of their duties--
of their power--to report to Congress on certain things, and that
this simply is taking further advantage of that power.

I have nothing further to add to this purely formal statement,
but, of course, I am at the disposal of the committee for questions.

Mr. SPEAKS. I want to ask the doctor whether, in his opinion, the
list of applicants for recognition would not very greatly increase
under the provisions of this bill?

Doctor BARROWS. I do not believe it would. As far as I could
get them from the War Department, I took the names of all of the
persons that had taken part in the experiments, and no others.

Mr. SPEAKS. But heretofore the action has been a voluntary one
on the part of the man who offered himself as a sacrifice. There
was no suggestion of reward. My thought is, Will not the fact
that a law of this nature is in existence be an inducement, and
cheapen just a little bit the character of the sacrifice? I am not
criticizing. This is just a thought that comes into my mind.

Doctor BARROWS. I can see that that is possible, and I have had
that in mind somewhat, with the fact that there are men who would
give all they could if it were not for the fact that they are burdened
with dependents and are living under circumstances that they can
not otherwise control.

Mr. SPEAKS. Thousands of men try to live up to that great prin-
ciple that “No greater love can a man have than that he give his
life for his friend.” At one time a close friend and comrade of
mine, of a very close association of years, heard a woman crying,
and responding immediately, he ran to see what was the matter, and
a colored man who was assaulting this woman shot and killed him
instantly. That was a voluntary act on his part, in response to an
impulse which is in the mind of every honest man--any real man
of high motives--which is to rush to the aid and assistance of any-
body in peril. But my thought was, here is an invitation; and I am
just fearful that it will induce a cheapening of the principle upon
which we expect to make awards. That is a suggestion, now, and
not a criticism.

Doctor BARROWS. I understand. As I stated, I can conceive of the
possibility of a man being spurred on by the fact that if he did act,
his dependents would be taken care of, possibly. After all, it does
not do a man very much good after his death to get a reward, cer-
tainly.

Mr. SPEAKS. I am not thinking of the men alone, but of the agency
which administers. It will be up to their judgment, first, to de-
termine and make the recommendation to Congress, and then it will
8
YELLOW FEVER
be for the Congress to decide whether it falls within that category
which should meet with reward.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. For that reason I would say we determined on
the high and disinterested agency of the Smithsonian Institution,
considering the character of the men that serve on the board of the
Smithsonian.

I notice we have two Members of Congress here whom I would
like to have you hear, and to suit their convenience I will call upon
them now, unless they would be willing to wait until this case is
entirely developed.
Mr. MOORE of Virginia. I am perfectly willing to wait, Colonel.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. General Ireland, I would like to call upon you
now to comment upon this legislation, particularly as to the accuracy
of this list, and how this would work, and what is the present status
of the individuals.

STATEMENT OF MAJ. GEN. M. W. IRELAND, SURGEON GENERAL
UNITED STATES ARMY

General IRELAND. Mr. Chairman and gentlemen, I am very glad
to appear before the committee in support of this bill, because my
distinguished predecessor, Gen. Robert M. O'Reilly, the greatest
Surgeon General that the Army ever had, made a similar recom-
mendation as far back as 1905. He prepared a memorandum which
was sent to the President, and which was forwarded to the Congress
with this comment [reading]:

The inclosed papers are transmitted to the Congress in the hope that it will
take suitable action in this matter. Major Reed's part in the experiments
which resulted in teaching us how to cope with yellow fever was such as to
render mankind his debtor, and this Government should in some proper fashion
bear witness to this fact.
THEODORE ROOSEVELT.
DECEMBER 5, 1906.

Walter Reed was the head of the board that went to Cuba in 1900
to discover, if possible, the cause of yellow fever. By October, 1900,
he had proven to his own satisfaction that it was caused by the mos-
quito. This was proven to the world very shortly afterwards, and
in proving that yellow fever was transmitted by a certain species
of mosquito, he made the greatest progress in preventive medicine
that had been made in the world up to that time; and I think it is
a very small thing for this Government to give a reward for those
who were connected with these experiments, and to my mind it does
seem very hard to divide the people who are interested into two cate-
gories: First, the board which consisted of Reed, Carroll, Lazear,
and Agramonte. They were the front and center that made these
experiments possible by their scientific attainments. Second, are the
volunteers who were bitten by mosquitoes and who contracted yellow
fever; third, are those volunteers who willingly went into a house
where the bedding and clothing of people who had had yellow fever
were placed, and slept in the bedding and clothing for a certain
number of nights, to determine whether they were infectious. It
seems as though that is a very simple way to divide the people who
had part in these experiments.

YELLOW FEVER
9

Mr. MCSWAIN. I would inquire if the General would not add a
fourth class, of those who submitted to subcutaneous inoculation of
blood from yellow-fever patients?
General IRELAND. If they had it.

Mr. MCSWAIN. Yes; if they contracted the disease. There were
some.

General IRELAND. There are several ways in which yellow fever
can be transmitted--by being bitten or by subcutaneous transmis-
sion of the blood of a patient.

That seems a simple way to subdivide those who had part in
these experiments, and it seems to me that for the first class; that
is, the individuals if they are living, or their widows, $3,000 a year
would be a suitable reward.
Mr. QUIN. What is the difference in the third class?

General IRELAND. They went into this building and wore clothing
and slept in bedding of yellow-fever patients. They did not know
at that time that they were not infectious. It was proven after-
wards that they were not infectious, and that they did not undergo
any danger whatever.

Mr. QUIN. Your three classes now include the men bitten by the
mosquito and the ones that had the blood transfusion?
General IRELAND. They are in the second class.
Mr. QUIN. And what is the first class?

General IRELAND. The board who had charge of this work, who
made this work possible.
Mr. QUIN. The doctors?

General IRELAND. Yes; the scientific men. They were all men of
scientific attainments, and they made this work possible.

Mr. QUIN. Your third class includes the gentlemen who went into
buildings and slept in there where yellow-fever patients had died?

General IRELAND. Yes; we know now that they did not take any
chances at all.
Mr. HILL of Alabama. That bedding was not very clean; was it?

General IRELAND. It certainly was not. There is a list here of the
people who took part in those experiments.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. Can you divide that list according to the classi-
fications you have made?

General IRELAND. Yes. Here is a list here of the people who took
charge of those experiments, and the names of the board, those inocu-
lated with yellow fever, and those exposed to infection only.
THE YELLOW FEVER ROLL OF HONOR
MEMBERS OF THE YELLOW FEVER BOARD

div1.p: The CHAIRMAN. Will you file that with us?
General IRELAND. Yes, sir.
The CHAIRMAN. Is that these names that are on file?
General IRELAND. Yes.
The CHAIRMAN. Also, will you mark them?

General IRELAND. If you will allow me, I will furnish you a copy
of this just as soon as I get to my office.

The CHAIRMAN. Have you compared the bill with the list you
are now referring to, and does it accurately cover all those that are
included in the categories?

General IRELAND. I think so. There were 4 members of the
board, 14 inoculated with yellow fever, and 4 who exposed them-
selves to bedding and clothing.
Mr. SPEAKS. Who were the four of the board?
General IRELAND. Reed, Carroll, Lazear, and Agramonte.
Mr. QUIN. Is Major Reed's wife getting any pension now?
General IRELAND. $125 a month.

Mr. QUIN. What you propose in here is to have her paid $2,000
a year?

General IRELAND. $3,000. The Secretary of War in 1902 recom-
mended that suitable rewards should be given to the people who put
this experiment through, and as the result the recommendation was
made that Walter Reed should be made a colonel--he was a major--
and that General Gorgas, who had no part in the experiments what-
ever but who was sanitary officer at Habana and who put into prac-
tical application the discoveries that the Walter Reed board made,
who put those discoveries into operation, should be made a lieutenant
colonel; but before that bill could be made a law Walter Reed died,
in November, 1902, and it was then recommended that Major Gorgas
be promoted to the grade of colonel, and that was done.
Mr. QUIN. Did his widow receive a pension?

General IRELAND. His widow, as I understand, sir, has received a
pension, but not for this work. I understand that Mrs. Gorgas has
a pension for the distinguished work that he did as sanitary officer
of Habana, Cuba, and as sanitary officer of the Isthmian Canal.

YELLOW FEVER
11
Mr. QUIN. My recollection is that I voted for it.
General IRELAND. I have no doubt you did, sir.
Mr. QUIN. Do you know what the amount was?
General IRELAND. No, sir; but I can find out and inform you.
Mr. QUIN. I do not want you to go to any trouble about it.
General IRELAND. It will be no trouble at all.

Mr. QUIN. I think she is entitled to it, and I believe Walter Reed's
widow is, too, and so far as I am concerned, I think all these folks
are.

Mr. HILL of Alabama. I do not want to put you off, but I want
to emphasize the fact that if it had not been for the discoveries of
that board we perhaps never could have built the Panama Canal.

General IRELAND. I agree to that. The French tried to build the
Panama Canal and failed. It could not be done because their
laborers died of yellow fever as fast as they sent them over there.
I think the world recognizes that the work of the Walter Reed board
made possible the regeneration of Cuba and the building of the
Panama Canal, and it has already resulted in eradicating yellow
fever from the Western Hemisphere, and in a very short time I am
sure it will result in eradicating yellow fever from the face of the
earth.

A tremendous work is now being done on the West Coast of Africa
by the Rockefeller Foundation, and the field work there is headed
by an eminent man who was in the Medical Corps when we went to
France, a Doctor Bute.
Mr. QUIN. Is he still in the service?

General IRELAND. No; he resigned. A man who is in the front
and center of that--we might as well speak well of the Medical
Department--is Frederick Russell, who remained in the Medical
Corps for 22 years and resigned as a colonel to be the chief of the
international health board under the Rockefeller Foundation.

Mr. QUIN. Some of these gentlemen who live in the North are not
acquainted with the awful ravages of the yellow fever. I live in that
country where it played the devil. I wish you would give some
outline of what the yellow fever meant.

General IRELAND. When I am talking to the General Staff--Major
Hammond is going to laugh now--I tell them what I told him, that
the discovery of Walter Reed pays this Government every year for
the entire expense of the Medical Department from the beginning,
for all time to come. I do not think that anyone has the imagination
to understand what an epidemic of yellow fever would mean in this
country to-day. Every summer the people from the South had to
leave their towns and go up North; they did not know what for, but
it was to get away from the mosquito.
Mr. QUIN. Tell them about New Orleans.

General IRELAND. In the last tremendous epidemic at New Orleans
they had thousands and thousands of people die there. So many
died that there were not enough well people to bury the dead.
Mr. QUIN. At home it devastated the country in 1878.

General IRELAND. It devastated the country in 1878, and if anyone
wants to look up the history of that epidemic they can do it very
well by reading Gould's History of the United States, in which he
describes it in the most graphic way.

12
YELLOW FEVER

With the way we are living now, with the quarantine that would
result every year if we could not control yellow fever and the expense
to this county of people moving out of the South away to the North,
and with the suspension of business, it would amount to a billion
dollars every year. No one could tell what it would amount to.

General IRELAND. That is opening up something that would keep
the Regents of the Smithsonian Institution busy all the time, and as
you are dealing here with one subject, it seems to me there should be
a limit of the work that would be thrown on the Regents, in some
way or other.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. Would you think that that limit would be
strong enough, that they be not required to consider any cases except
those sent up to them by a chief of a department?

General IRELAND. I think so. There would have to be some way
to get rid of all of the self-seekers and the cranks.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. We have here to-day some of the members of
the Board of Regents, and we are going to invite their frank com-
ments on this subject.
General IRELAND. That will be much better than my discussion.

Mr. SPEAKS. I have forgotten the details of the organization of
that commission and the manner in which the men who made the
sacrifice were selected. Was the commission organized--did they
ask for volunteers--with an understanding as to the possibilities in
the service, etc.?

General IRELAND. To start with, the Surgeon General of the Army,
Gen. George M. Sternberg, was a great investigator, and among
other things he investigated yellow fever. He had had cholera in
1867, and he had worked with yellow fever for years, and had some
ideas about the organism that transmitted yellow fever.

When our troops went to Cuba and they were having yellow fever,
and so much yellow fever, he recommended that a board be con-
vened to go to Cuba and study yellow fever, and the board was as is
mentioned here.

After Walter Reed had eliminated all of these theories that had
grown up in 50 years as to the transmission of yellow fever--and
that was a very easy thing for him to do--he took up the transmis-
sion of yellow fever by the mosquito, which had been postulated by
a Doctor Finley, of Habana, since 1881. He investigated the differ-
ent experiments that Doctor Finley had made; and during all these
years Doctor Finley had insisted that this was the way yellow fever
was transmitted, but he never could prove it in a scientific way.

After Walter Reed had eliminated these preliminary claims, he
came to the point where he had to have human experimentation to
determine the mosquito theory, and when that time came, accom-
panied by Colonel Kean he went to General Wood, who as you re-
member was a doctor, and told him of his troubles, and asked for
authority to ask for volunteers to be bitten by infected mosquitoes.
General Wood not only gave him the authority, but he gave him the
money to either pay these men or to give them presents.

Colonel Kean is going to speak to you, and he knows more about
those experiments than any other living being except Doctor Agra-
YELLOW FEVER
13
monte. Colonel Kean was for years right with him, his friend for
years, and he handled the money by which these volunteers were
paid, and has an intimate knowledge of it, and he has written prac-
tically all the literature that has been sent to Congress on yellow
fever.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. We have invited Congressman Davenport to
comment on this matter, and he has an engagement which requires
him to leave, and I am going to ask him now to say a word to the
committee.

STATEMENT OF HON. FREDERICK M. DAVENPORT, A REPRE-
SENTATIVE IN CONGRESS FROM THE STATE OF NEW YORK

Mr. DAVENPORT. Mr. Chairman and gentlemen of the committee,
with respect to the first section of the bill, I think the committee
should consider whether or not a flat pension to all the persons men-
tioned is the proper thing or, rather, the differentiated pension as
has been suggested.

About section 2, as I have listened here I have felt some misgiv-
ings about an investigating authority that seems to be put in the
position of ferreting out these cases. It seems to me it is perhaps
going too far, and the question arises whether it is not better to have
spontaneous heroism make its appeal to public opinion rather than to
set up a distinct machinery of authority.

But what I came to say especially is this: It seems to me that we
are considering in this bill the very highest form of heroism. We
all recognize the importance of rewarding in public opinion and in
other ways the heroism of the Army and the Navy; yet I am won-
dering whether this kind of heroism is not even a higher kind than
that which is often associated with men of the Army and Navy.
I am wondering whether it is not easier sometimes to face the music
of the guns when your blood is up and you have all your comrades
around you and you have the collective pressure close to you so that
you can feel it, than it is to do what John Kissinger did--to walk in
to Walter Reed and say to him that he was ready to go ahead with
this deadly experiment; and after Walter Reed had cross-examined
him and found that he knew just exactly what he was doing, I am
not at all surprised that Maj. Walter Reed saluted Pvt. John Kis-
singer. It seems to me it is the highest form of heroism to do that
sort of thing. To deal with a matter of this kind in the way con-
templated by the bill is one of the ways of putting a spirit of con-
fidence in the Government of the United States into the rising genera-
tion of young men and women of this country. I do not like very
well the evidence that we have around us sometimes of the lack of
a genuine confidence in the Government of the United States; the
jocose way in which in many places the Government of the United
States is spoken of, and the lawless manner in which so many people
in this country seem to act in defiance of the Government of the
United States. And I know that cases like these yellow-fever ex-
periment cases are the subject of discussion among our young folks.
I have happened to be an educator most of my life, before I got into
public affairs, and even since I got into public affairs, and I know
that cases like this are known and commented upon and read about
and talked about among the young men and women who are growing
14
YELLOW FEVER
up in this country, and I am anxious to see such injustices cured, so
that there will not be any question that these boys and girls who are
just now at the Easter vacation crowding the streets of Washington
from all over the country, with awe and reverence for the Govern-
ment of the United States in their hearts, may never have any reason
to say, “Well, the Government is not what I thought it was.”

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. I wonder if the concluding thought of my
colleague is not in favor of some such procedure as is provided in
section 2 of this bill?

Mr. DAVENPORT. If it is simple enough so that it does not make
mechanical the whole procedure, yes; but otherwise, no.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. I remember that the hour of the session of the
House is approaching, and we have another Member of Congress
here whom I have invited, and we are very much gratified that he is
here. He is one of the Regents of the Smithsonian, our colleague, Mr.
Moore, of Virginia, and I would like to have his comment on this
measure.

STATEMENT OF HON. R. WALTON MOORE, A REPRESENTATIVE
IN CONGRESS FROM THE STATE OF VIRGINIA

Mr. MOORE. Mr. Chairman and gentlemen of the committee, I
knew nothing about this bill until an hour or so ago, and as the
Secretary of the Board of Regents of the Smithsonian Institution
is here, I shall ask him to discuss the second section.

I think if that section is adopted it will certainly be necessary
to apply such limitations as will save the Board of Regents from
almost endless work in making investigations. That is a point
which I simply leave with the committee.

With respect to the first section of the bill, it seems to me, from
my point of view, that there should be no hesitation in giving it
very sympathetic consideration. Just the other day the House
passed a bill having reference to General Gorgas, who is recognized
as the greatest sanitarian the world has ever known, in his applica-
tion of the discoveries made by the Walter Reed Board with a view
to the successful extermination of yellow fever.

By the way, at one time, recurring to a question that was asked
a while ago, the yellow fever ravaged this country as far north as
Boston. I read recently a book written by an English traveler in
this country in 1800, who spoke of having landed in New York and
having made his way to Philadelphia where he found that yellow
fever was raging to such an extent that he was afraid to stay there,
and then came along southward, and reached South Carolina where
he found the same condition obtained.

As for the Walter Reed Board, there can not be the slightest mis-
giving that, under the leadership and direction of Walter Reed, it
performed such a service as had never been performed before and
has never been duplicated. There never has been such a valuable
investigation of the cause of a dreadful disease, paving the way to
the method of eliminating that disease. General Gorgas himself
spoke of that board as “the now famous and immortal board.”

If any men are entitled to such immortality as can be given them
in the public estimation by a suitable recognition by the Govern-
YELLOW FEVER
15
ment of the United States, it seems to me they are the people who are
designated in the first section of this bill.

I shall not say anything now about Reed, because my friend, Colonel
Kean, my friend of a lifetime--he and I were desk mates at school----
Mr. HILL of Alabama. Is the colonel a Virginian?

Mr. MOORE of Virginia. Yes; a Virginian, just as Walter Reed
was a Virginian. The little, humble house stands in old Gloucester
County to this day where Walter Reed first saw the light.

As I said, Colonel Kean was his right-hand man in the great
adventure and achievement in Habana, and all that we can know now
about Walter Reed in addition to what the books contain Colonel
Kean is able to tell us.

Mr. MCSWAIN. In that connection I would suggest that another
Virginian, Dr. Robert P. Cook was there doing duty in various ways
as a contract surgeon.

Mr. MOORE of Virginia. There never was a more self-sacrificing
man than Reed or than the gentlemen who were associated with him
and worked under his direction. I do not think you can search his-
tory and find any such shining examples of long and unquestioned
self-sacrifice as those people made. I may say that my friend, Colonel
Kean, was one of the men who contracted the dreadful yellow-fever
disease while the work of the board was going on at Habana.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. Colonel Kean needs no introduction from me
after the introduction he has already had, and I am sure the com-
mittee will be glad to hear him. Colonel, will you give your name
and your present occupation and your service in the Army?

STATEMENT OF COL. JEFFERSON R. KEAN, UNITED STATES
ARMY, RETIRED

Colonel KEAN. Colonel Jefferson R. Kean, United States Army,
retired. I am at present secretary of the Association of Military
surgeons of the United States.

Gentlemen, I have not the gift of distinct statement and public
speaking that my old schoolmate, Congressman Moore, has, so that
I will not attempt to make any statement. I will probably repeat
things that you already know and that have already been said. My
idea is, therefore, that I will just state what my connection was with
this famous episode, such as it was, and then ask you to ask me ques-
tions. I am sure that in that way I will save your time and get at
the meat of the matter better than by wandering all over the whole
story, which is a long story, and in the course of which I might get
into bypaths that would not interest you.

I happened to be in Cuba at the end of the Spanish War as chief
surgeon of the Seventh Army Corps, which was commanded by Gen.
Fitzhugh Lee, and headquarters of the corps were at Quemada, just
outside of Habana.

After the volunteer army was sent home General Lee was kept
there in command of the regular troops that were brought down,
and there was a base at Quemada Barracks, which was the main gar-
rison in Cuba, and he remained in command of the local department.

At the time that Walter Reed came to Cuba he commanded the
department of western Cuba, which included the western end of the
103083--28--PT 1---2
16
YELLOW FEVER
island, the Provinces of Habana and Pinar del Rio, but excepted the
city of Habana, which was under a separate military command. I
was General Lee's chief surgeon and had charge of sanitary matters
outside of the city of Habana. Major Gorgas was the sanitary officer
of the city of Habana.

I had known Reed before he came down there. I happened to be
sick with yellow fever at the time he came down, and he came right
out to see me. I think I was the first case he ever saw.

Reed and his board came, naturally, to Quemada Barracks, be-
cause they could get quarters there without expense and it would be
in a perfectly healthy region where they would not be exposed to
contract the disease themselves, and they would have the assistance
of the Military Establishment.

As the chief surgeon for the medical instrumentalties there, I was
very delighted to put them at his disposition, and I was interested in
going through all the steps of these experiments. They were very
wonderful, and the interest and excitement was such that I could
often hardly sleep at night.

He arrived on June 25, 1900, and the summer was spent, as General
Ireland has said, in removing false fears; and then they took up the
Finley theory, that old Doctor Finley had been advocating for 30
years and had not been able to demonstrate. A theory that is not
demonstrated is of no value at all in the opinion of scientific men.

I do not think it is necessary for me to go into details of those
experiments, but I would suggest, Mr. Wainwright, that you ask me
questions about things that are not clear.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. I will ask you to take the bill, and take the list
of names, and state as briefly as possible what each one of those
people did. I am sure it will take you but a short time.

Colonel KEAN. I am very glad to do that. Three out of the four
members of the Reed board are now dead, and their widows, Mrs.
Walter Reed, Mrs. James Carroll, and Mrs. Lazear are still living.
✓ Doctor Agramonte is still alive. He is a very fine man. I know him
very well. He has a position in the medical school in Habana.
Mr. WAINWRIGHT. He was a member of that board?

Colonel KEAN. He was a member of that board. He is a person
who should be remembered in any action taken by the Congress of
the United States. His history is briefly this: His father was killed
in battle against the Spaniards. Agramonte was brought by his
family as a little boy to New York. He was educated at Columbia
University.

He became during the Spanish war a contract surgeon, an acting
assistant surgeon in the Army of the United States. After that, he
was sent to Habana.

He was put on this board. He and Lazear both went to Columbia,
I think. He and Lazear were both in Habana at that time. They
were made members of this board, Reed and Carroll coming down
from Washington.

Agramonte's services as a member of that board, unfortunately,
in the printed report, this Senate document, are not fairly stated.
That is the official report, the one that Mr. Roosevelt sent to Con-
gress. I prepared that statement for Surgeon General O'Reilly,
and I was misinformed at that time, and I am sorry to say I did
not do Agramonte justice.

YELLOW FEVER
17
Mr. WAINWRIGHT. May in interrupt you?
Colonel KEAN. Yes.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. Are you referring now to the document which
gives in narrative form the service that each one of those individuals
performed?

Colonel KEAN. Yes; it is a memorandum that states what each
man's service was, and what emolument he received, and so on, and
there is a list at the end of it giving the names.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. Will you proceed with each one of those, just
as briefly as possible, realizing the limitations of our time?

Colonel KEAN. Mrs. Walter Reed is the first one. At the time of
Reed's death he had been nominated to be a colonel, but he died
before he got it. The service proposed that Congress give Mrs.
Reed his pay as a pension. The amount was cut down to $125 a
month, which is not enough for a lady to live on.
Mr. FROTHINGHAM. What does she get now?
Colonel KEAN. $125 a month.

Mr. FROTHINGHAM. This committee last year reported a bill--
through Mr. McSwain, as I understand it--increasing various
amounts.

Mr. MCSWAIN. No; it only referred to the pension of Dr. Robert
P. Cooke.
Mr. FROTHINGHAM. What would you give them?

Colonel KEAN. It seems to me that the amount the Surgeon Gen-
eral proposes in this bill for Mrs. Reed, Mrs. Carroll, Mrs. Lazear,
and Doctor Agramonte should go. It is the least Congress can do;
and I do not think Congress should leave out Doctor Agramonte in
any action they take. He is, of course, a Cuban.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. We have such a limited time; we are almost up
to 12 o'clock now, and we have two other speakers, so that possibly,
if a statement of exactly what each one of these did is in some docu-
ment, if you can refer us to that document, that would be sufficient.
Colonel KEAN. I have a list of the categories.

Mr. MCSWAIN. Mr. Chairman, I am going to ask that Colonel
Kean extend his remarks at length by stating just as freely as he
wants to, to get a stenographer or use his pen, and state for our
record, so that it will be printed and bound in the volume of this
hearing fully and completely, just as fully as he pleases, everything
in regard to this matter. Write a book as thick as this, Colonel
[indicating], and we will have it printed.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. Will you include the present age of each of
those persons?
Colonel KEAN. Yes; and their addresses, if possible.
Mr. MCSWAIN. Yes.

Mr. JAMES. Did you have something to do with drawing up this
bill, Colonel?

Colonel KEAN. Indirectly. The Surgeon General consulted me
about various elements of it, and I think he had some correspondence
about it. Directly, I did not have anything to do with it.
Mr. JAMES. In line 16, on page 2, there is this language:

And the Secretary of War is hereby directed to pay to the foregoing, during
the remainder of their natural lives, the sum of $250 per month in lieu of any
and all pensions now received.

18
YELLOW FEVER

Is that on the Treasury Department bill or the War Department
appropriation bill, or what?

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. I am going to ask, when we get through with
this hearing, that this bill be submitted to Mr. Frothingham's subcom-
mittee for the purpose of going over it and making the obvious prac-
tical amendments to it that would be required to make it effective.
I realize the justice of the implied criticism.

Doctor Abbott, the Secretary of the Board of Regents of the Smith-
sonian Institution, is here, and I have invited him to give us his
frank comment on this measure and to tell us how it could be handled
practically and how it should be restricted for practical handling by
the Board of Regents.

STATEMENT OF DR. CHARLES G. ABBOTT, SECRETARY OF THE
SMITHSONIAN INSTITUTION

Doctor ABBOTT. I am quite sure that the committee is sympathetic
to the first section of the bill and I will not speak of that.
Section 2 provides as follows:

SEC. 2. That the Board of Regents of the Smithsonian Institution is hereby
authorized to investigate all cases of citizens employed in the public service of
the United States who through voluntary risk of life and health shall have
rendered conspicuous service to the people of the country.

This language does not seem to me, sir, to shut out all those who
might volunteer in the military and naval service of the United
States and render valuable services. There might be millions of
them, and I think the language should be so modified as to shut out
all those. They are treated in the pension laws of the United States.

Then the question would arise whether the Board of Regents
should be authorized to seek out individuals. Apparently this lan-
guage, “to investigate all cases,” would impose upon them the require-
ment that they should look out and find such cases. It would seem
to me that that would be a very onerous charge; that it would be much
more than perhaps all the other work of the institution combined.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. I think the sponsors of this bill will recognize
that, and we would be glad to have some practical suggestions about
how we could limit this and limit it in a practical way.

Doctor ABBOTT. Mr. Moore suggested to me a few moments ago
that it might be limited to those who are recommended by the heads
of the other departments of the Government so that that would cut
it down to a moderate amount.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. In other words, this bill only covers public
employees. Every public employee has a function under some de-
partment or bureau, and if it was required that the Regents of the
Smithsonian should consider only cases that were vouched for and
recommended by the heads of bureaus----

Doctor ABBOTT. You understand, the term “public employees”
does not shut out employees of the Army and Navy, and if they were
included, there might be millions of them. It should be, if the Secre-
tary of War recommended to us some particular cases, which he
thought came under this sort of thing. It should not be cases which
would come under the pension service of the United States.

It seems to me, sir, that the function of the Smithsonian in this
matter, if indeed the duty be devolved upon the Smithsonian, must
YELLOW FEVER
19
be that of judging cases for which the evidence has been collected
and submitted to the Institution by the heads of the various public
departments. It seems to me that it should be specifically stated who
shall impose this duty upon the institution, because you can see that
it might otherwise swamp us and prevent us from performing other
duties with which we are charged.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. I think we are contemplating the regents of the
institution sitting in an absolutely judicial capacity, with the evi-
dence and the whole case prepared for them to consider.

Doctor ABBOTT. I would like to ask Mr. Moore whether, under
those circumstances, he thinks the board would be willing to assume
this duty.

Mr. MOORE of Virginia. I should say, offhand, not speaking for
the board, if the cases would be rather few in number, that there
would be no difficulty in the board giving a decision in the way of
making a recommendation in each case.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. Fine! I am very much gratified with that sug-
gestion from the gentleman.

Doctor ABBOTT. I suppose with the understanding that the ma-
chinery by which the Smithsonian would act would be that the Sec-
retary would, with the advice of eminent advisers, select a committee
or a board to pass upon each case as it came up, and would submit
the recommendation of such a committee to Congress, and in the
event that the institution was merely a judge and not a collector of
evidence, and the cases were limited as has been suggested, it would
seem to me that it might be possible that that should be done.

Mr. WAINWRIGHT. Let us consider a concrete case, the case of a
man name Leroy Kerle, an assistant biologist in the United States
Department of Public Health, who died as the result of infection
with Rocky Mountain spotted fever contracted in the course of the
experimental work in the Government laboratory at Hamilton, Mont.
That is the case that I believe I referred to that was mentioned in
the press last Sunday. That would be a case where the Public
Health Service, who are here represented to-day, would prepare
their case and present it to your board for consideration.

Doctor ABBOTT. Our institution would be charged with the duty of
recommending the amount and nature of the pension. That would
not amount to anything, because Congress would have to consider it
in detail and decide upon it finally, so that even if the Smithsonian
should recommend adversely upon a case and send such a recommen-
dation to Congress, or should recommend favorably, but not satisfac-
torily to the claimant, Congress would still have the opportunity of
amending the recommendation. In other words, the recommendation
of the Smithsonian would not be final, but would be a guide to
Congress. That is your intention.
Mr. WAINWRIGHT. I think the bill so provides.

Doctor ABBOTT. I think that might be specially limited in the way
we have suggested here.

STATEMENT OF DR. A. M. STIMSON, ASSISTANT SURGEON
GENERAL, PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE

Doctor STIMSON. I know that if Doctor Cumming were here he
would indorse the recommendations in favor of the first section of
the bill and of the second section as modified.

The second section comes very close to us in the Public Health
Service. The statement has been made here this morning that three
men have died in the service in connection with the spotted fever
investigation at Hamilton, Mont. As a matter of fact, six men have
given their lives there; and any man who goes there to work in that
laboratory knows well enough that he is facing a high chance of
death.

The originator of the new vaccine against this disease, which is
proving to be useful in the control of it, Doctor Spencer, inoculated
himself first with this vaccine, to decide whether or not it was safe
to give it to other people, and he has not had spotted fever yet, and
YELLOW FEVER
21
hopes that he will not have it; but six men who worked in this labora-
tory have died, and four others have contracted the disease and
recovered. Those who recovered, as we think, recovered because of
having been treated, or partially because of having been treated, with
this vaccine.

There are other cases which the United States Public Health
Service investigate, which, while not as fatal as this, have exposed
the individual who is working on them to chronic disease. We have
two members of the service now suffering from a fever from which
they have suffered for a number of years--in one case almost totally
incapacitating the worker. This service was always undertaken with
the full understanding that they were in danger. Several of those
who have worked with it--in fact, all of those who have worked
indirectly with it--have had the disease, and in one or two cases the
results have been quite serious.

I think that some modification of section 2 ought certainly to be
made in order to enable the Government to recognize services of this
kind that may take place in the future.
